title: What's the difference between filing for bankruptcy and getting a charge off if trying to go with a Debt Settlement Company?
question: I heard that the charge off sstays in my credit score for 7 years just lke a bankruptcy, what's a better option? and how can I verify that the Debt Settlement Company I've been talking to is legit?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit score,Credit,Debt,Debt settlement,Bankruptcy and debt,Federal crime,Court orders,Federal court
answers:
Any debt forgiven outside of bankruptcy constitutes income for federal income tax purposes. In other word, if a company you owe $10,000 tells you that you only have to pay back $7,000 to fully satify the obligation, then you have $3,000 federal income for tax purposes from this trasnaction. This is not the case when debts are discharged in bankruptcy.

These comments are not legal advice and are made for educational purposes only. No attorney-client relationship exists between us.

A "charge off" isn't any sort of legal change in your obligation to pay. All the term means is that the creditor moves the debt to the "bad debt" collection. Ultimately, most 'charge fofs" are sold to debt buyers, who then sue you. it may be many years later, I have heard of some that sue 12 years later.

Beware of anything calling itself a "debt settlement company". These are generally scams.

If a debt is discharged in bankruptcy, that means that you have no further legal obligation to pay it..

Please note that I do not practice in your state and that the above is not intended as legal advice, it is for educational purposes only. No attorney-client relationship is created or is intended to be created hereby. You should contact a local attorney to discuss and to obtain legal advice.

If you discharge the debt in a bankruptcy you will have a Federal Court Order as opposed to whatever you may or may not receive from the debt settlement company. You will also not recieve a 1099 if you discharge the debt in bankruptcy,and there will be no negative tax implications. Therefore, unless you have substantial non-exempt assets, the bankruptcy would be the preferred option. Finally, there is no particular agency that governs debt settlement companies(a problem), so the best you can do is the better business bureau,or state attorney general, and make sure there are no complaints.
